repnme.cdata!:
Madagascar - Irrigation and Watershed
            Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Irrigation and Watershed
            Management Project for Madagascar were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately unsatisfactory, global environment objective
            (GEO) outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, risk to
            development outcome was high, risk to GEO outcome was high,
            Bank performance was moderately unsatisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was moderately satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: the project did not achieve all its
            planned outcomes but built a strong basis on which new
            operations can be (and are being indeed) prepared. Regarding
            institutional arrangements, the project demonstrated that it
            is possible, and recommended, to rely on the Ministry of
            Agriculture’s structure, reinforced with adequate technical
            assistance (TA) and the support of an external financial
            management agency, to implement agricultural projects. The
            project also demonstrated the validity of the integrated
            watershed approach and the strong interest that
            beneficiaries take in that approach. The multiannual
            performance contract (PC) approach and the montant d’apport
            préalable estimé réaliste (MAPER) combined with the
            formalization of Dina proved to be useful tools to generate
            ownership and mobilize the irrigation scheme users and to
            consolidate their Water User Associations (WUAs). In a
            context of an ever increasing fragmentation of land in
            irrigated areas, a strong emphasis should be put on
            agricultural intensification and diversification in uplands.
            Future projects should also be more gender sensitive in
            order to draw on the generally observed dynamism of women
            and women associations in soil conservation,
            intensification, diversification, marketing, and processing
            activities. More attention has to be paid to establishing an
            adequate monitoring and evaluation (M and E) system that is
            able to define and correctly monitor useful output and
            outcome indicators and that does not neglect the evaluation
            aspect, in order to provide project management with impact
            and sustainability assessments that may induce shifts in
            strategies and resources during the project life.

repnme.cdata!:
Madagascar - Irrigation and Watershed
            Management Project : resettlement plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Irrigation and
            Watershed Management Project is to contribute to inclusive
            rural growth, through the promotion of intensification and
            diversification in three regions, with high potential for
            agricultural development, in addition to the promotion of
            sustainable infrastructure, and soil and water resources.
            This resettlement action plan (RAP) evaluates impacts
            associated with the implementation of the project, and
            recommends mitigation measures as follows. Compliance with
            the Bank's Operational Directive on resettlement, and
            with the country's institutional and legislative
            framework (in particular the Expropriation Law 62.023 of
            September 1962) will apply during project implementation.
            The acquisition of land and other assets, and resettlement
            issues will be minimized as much as possible through project
            design, particularly regarding site selection. Project
            affected peoples (PAPs) will be compensated, relocated and
            rehabilitated so that their livelihoods improve, or at least
            their standard of living is restored, including their income
            earning capacity, to pre-project levels. Grievance
            mechanisms shall be in place, as will the provision of free
            legal assistance for conflict resolution, for tenure
            regularization, and transfer of titles. It is a paramount
            priority to address the needs of vulnerable groups (women,
            children, orphans, handicap persons, people without land,
            and the elderly), ensuring compliance with this framework.
            Public consultation will be promoted to inform PAPs on
            policies, legislation and compensation due, prior
            implementation of land acquisition and the subsequent resettlement.

repnme.cdata!:
Madagascar - Irrigation and Watershed
            Management Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The pest management plan (V. 1)
            addresses issues related to the Madagascar Irrigation and
            Watershed Management Project, which improves agricultural
            production and soil and water management by increasing
            irrigation infrastructure and integrated pest management to
            be used to grow rice and diversify crops. The report
            assesses the risks to human health and the environment
            associated with acquiring, storing and maintaining, and
            disposing of and using pesticides; discusses risk prevention
            through training and education of workers and the public,
            protective equipment for workers, and regulation and
            legislation. It also evaluates the capacity of
            Madagascar's institutions to control and regulate
            pesticides while assigning roles and responsibilities; and
            identifies pest types and discusses strategies to control
            their spread-especially the control of mosquitoes and the
            prevention of malaria. Specific risks it identifies include
            soil contamination and water resources contamination,
            including leaching leading to water table pollution, and
            groundwater and underground water pollution; as well as
            accidental ingestion of chemicals, inhalation by residents
            of fumes and dust, and skin contact with the actual
            substances. Beyond those measures already mentioned, the
            report recommends an integrated approach to pest management,
            installing emergency procedures in case of accidents,
            promoting the effective use of alternatives, and
            environmental monitoring. Also addressed are those issues
            related with regional environmental and social assessments
            for each project site - Maravoay, Itasy, Andapa, and Alaotra
            - (v. 2 through 5), and its mitigation measures.
